content: The text chunk discusses the conversion of property and facilities at closed or realigned military installations into youthful offender boot camps. The Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 allows for the conversion of closed or realigned military installations into youthful offender boot camps, with notification to relevant parties before any disposal or transfer of property. The Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 permits the conversion of closed military installations into youthful offender boot camps, with notification to relevant parties. The Secretary must receive certification within 180 days, including a conversion and operating plan. If multiple certifications are received, the recipient will be chosen based on the quality and feasibility of the plans. Private certifications may be rejected if deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 allows closed military installations to be converted into youthful offender boot camps. The Secretary may reject certification if the conversion plan is deemed unlikely to succeed or if the State or local government opposes the transfer. A youthful offender boot camp is defined as a military-style facility for non-violent offenders aged 14 to 25. The Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 allows closed military installations to be converted into youthful offender boot camps. Any certification for conversion must be submitted within 180 days and include a conversion and operating plan. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with relevant agencies, will develop a model program for incorporating military-style discipline and training for non-violent offenders aged 14 to 25. Youthful offender boot camps are correctional facilities operated as military-style boot camps for non-violent offenders aged 14 to 25, providing discipline, treatment, and work opportunities. Amendment to section 516 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 reduces the number of grants for boot camps from 80 to 40 and increases the allocation from 10 to 50.
